/sources/Priorities-and-GTD.title: Priorities and GTD
/sources/Priorities-and-GTD.content:
https://gettingthingsdone.com/2018/03/priorities-and-gtd/
*Kelly Forrister*

How to decide what to do:

1. Context: What is required to do what you want to do. If you don't have that priority is irrelevant
1. Time Available: If you don't have time then it doesn't matter either
1. Resources: Do you have the energy to do it?
1. Priority: Once all of those things have been met then Priority matters.

When prioritizing ask yourself two questions:
Whats the value in getting this done?
What bad will happen if I don't?

If you aren’t crystal clear on your priorities, climb up the *Horizons of Focus*, especially to *Areas of Focus* to know what you are actually responsible for personally and professionally. Many times people will do that and realize they have things on their projects and next actions lists that are not really their job. If you are not sure what your areas are (most people have 5–7 personally and 5–7 professionally) then maybe it’s time for some updates on that with people you think can help you get clear on that.

https://youtu.be/65U5byDZ55M

* Write [Morning Pages](Morning%20Pages.md).
* Write 2 crappy pages per day
* Edit in three passes: first for yourself, then the fans, lastly the critics
* Find a professional writer or someone with legal training to read your writing and give you feedback. Their job has them focus on the details and how things are written 
* Have a normal person read your writing and highlight any part that is unclear. People can agree or disagree with your writing, but everyone should understand it.

 > When in doubt, take it out.

/sources/The-Dash-Plus-System.title: The Dash Plus System
/sources/The-Dash-Plus-System.content:
Author: *Patrick Rhone*
URL: https://patrickrhone.com/dashplus/

*Capture Tools*
*Analog*
*Handwritten Daily Notes*
*Tools for thought*

(Dash): Undone Action Item — Individual items (action items and ideas) are marked with a dash preceding them. All items, no matter what they are, are therefore treated as items to be processed.

(Plus): Done Action Item — If the item is an action item (todo), when the item is complete, a vertical line is drawn through the “dash” thus making it resemble a “plus”. This makes the dashed items stand out quite well despite the fact that the same color pen or pencil may be used.

(Right Arrow): Waiting – (i.e. for another action) — Drawing an arrow pointing to the the item denotes that it is something that is waiting on another action to happen or deliverable.

(Left Arrow): Delegated — Drawing an arrow pointing to the left of the item denotes that it has been delegated (with a note to whom and the date) .

(Triangle): Data Point — Turning the dash into a triangle denotes a data point (a fact or figure you wish to remember for instance).

(Circle) — A circle around any of the above means that it has been carried forward, moved to another list or otherwise changed status – i.e. a “Waiting” item has now become an Action Item elsewhere (with a note about where that item has gone).

/sources/The-Tickler-File.title: The Tickler File
/sources/The-Tickler-File.content:
Author: *David Allen*
URL: https://gettingthingsdone.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/2016-Tickler-File-.pdf

The Tickler File is an organizational tool which can be used to simplify the tracking of date-related items and to manage work flow. It works well as an adjunct to personal planners and calendars, allowing them to be used for streamlined focus on items that require on-going review and access. The Tickler is also referred to as “perpetual file,” “bring-forward file,” “follow-up file,” or “suspense file.”

If you want to be reminded to handle something in the future, but don’t want or need to think about it until then, it can be “tickled” to show up exactly on the day or month you’d like to see it again.

Slice of life: some real things in my tickler file—DA

* Amtrak ticket for the day I need it

What I've been building in [TickTick](../TickTick.md) with Routines is effectively a digital tickler file

https://youtu.be/zsPgNuuS8pA

On *Sleep*. Needs 8 hours of it, unless traveling in which case all bets are off.

As a high level executive you are paid to make a few high quality decisions. Not 100s of decisions, just a key few. 
[Executives are paid to make a few key decisions](../Executives%20are%20paid%20to%20make%20a%20few%20key%20decisions.md)

Executives at places like *Amazon* should be working a year plus out. The current quarter should have been baked a good bit of time ago and now just needs to be executed. 

Trading a few hours of sleep to make more decisions, but at a lower quality is not a good decision in a company like Amazon, but may be more appropriate in a *startup* context.

/sources/Why-good-leaders-make-you-feel-.title: Why good leaders make you feel safe
/sources/Why-good-leaders-make-you-feel-.content:
By *Simon Sinek*
https://youtu.be/lmyZMtPVodo

Heroics are built on *trust* and *cooperation*.

Leaders set the *tone* and *environment*. When we feel safe we will combine our talents and strengths and work tirelessly to face the challenges of our company. Great *leadership* is like child-rearing, but with adults.

Head count vs Heart count

We should all suffer a little instead of one of us suffer a lot. This in a scenario of necessary cuts to the labor pool they instead required each employee to take 4 weeks unpaid vacation. They could take it anytime and it didn’t have to be consecutive. *Morale* actually went up.

Leadership is a choice. Leadership is different than *authority*. People choose to follow great leaders other have to listen because they have authority over them.

When leaders show they are willing to *sacrifice* for their people then their people will choose to sacrifice for them to see their *vision* come to life.

/tmux.title: tmux
/tmux.content:
Relates to [Shell](Shell.md)

## Basics

### Start a new tmux session

`tmux`

### Relaunch an existing tmux session

`tmux attach`

## Detach from Session

`Ctrl+b d` or close the window

### Move between panes

`Ctrl+b o`

Split the window horizontally
`Ctrl+b %`

Split the window vertically
`Ctrl+b "`

## Make your sessions persistent with

https://github.com/tmux-plugins/tmux-continuum
https://github.com/tmux-plugins/tmux-resurrect
